title: How Do I Tell My Friend to Stop Paying for His Son’s Lifestyle?
description: A reader wants his golfing buddy to stop complaining about his over-age dependent.
content: My friend’s son is a deadbeat. He’s 35, still lives at home, has never kept a job for longer than a year, buys things he can’t afford, and now his pregnant girlfriend is moving in. He has a million excuses for everything that goes wrong. It’s never his fault! The problem: My friend and I play golf three times a week, and I can’t tolerate listening to him complain about his son anymore. How do I tell him to wise up and stop supporting him? I don’t want to hurt my friend, but he needs to hear the truth.

content: “I Am Woman,” a pleasant, yet disappointingly trite biopic of the singer Helen Reddy, has a flatness that’s difficult to ascribe to any one element. As Reddy, Tilda Cobham-Hervey has warmth and gumption; the 1960s-80s production design is impeccable; and the cinematography, by the celebrated Dion Beebe (the partner of the director, Unjoo Moon), is richly textured.

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week

content: Our recommended books this week are evenly balanced between questions of race and space. First, the cosmos: In “The Sirens of Mars,” the planetary scientist Sarah Stewart Johnson evokes the wonders of her work looking for life on other worlds; in “The End of Everything,” the theoretical cosmologist Katie Mack asks what science can teach us about the likely end of the universe; and in “The Smallest Lights in the Universe,” the astrophysicist Sara Seager balances an account of her scientific career with a memoir of grief and young widowhood. On the subject of race, Seyward Darby (“Sisters in Hate”) and Edward Ball (“Life of a Klansman”) both probe America’s troubled legacy of white supremacy, while Martha S. Jones (“Vanguard”) celebrates the Black women who have persevered in the cause of equal justice.

content: Montana is a land of stunning natural variety — grassy plains and snowcapped mountains, Yellowstone and Glacier National Parks, crystal streams full of glittering trout and one of America’s largest Superfund sites — but perhaps its most abundant resource is self-awareness. I have never lived in a place where so many people’s shirts said what state we were in. Montanans live within a kind of paradox by which they regard their own home as exotic. Nicknamed the Treasure State, it is more commonly called the Last Best Place or Big Sky Country. Both epithets are constructed in the negative: “Big Sky” refers to the general absence of tall buildings, and the “Last Best Place” implies a fallen world outside its borders. It is tempting to dismiss this attitude as provincial, but it seems most popular among the many coastal expatriates who experience Montana as a respite from the lives they left behind. To native and transplant alike, Montana is the only place that isn’t everywhere else.

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: London Offices Aren’t Refilling Fast Enough for Shops Relying on Them
description: The British government and business lobby want workers to return to support surrounding businesses, but some city offices are only 15 percent full.
content: LONDON — Schroders, a big asset management firm, wants more of its workers to return to its office in the City of London. Over the summer, it encouraged people to come in for a day to test their commute and so the firm could demonstrate the new safety measures in place, including an app to order food from the canteen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Rockets’ ‘Microball’ Puts P.J. Tucker at the Center of Chaos
description: Tucker isn’t the tallest player on the Houston Rockets, but that doesn’t stop him from challenging opponents’ big men, like Anthony Davis of the Los Angeles Lakers.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — The joke doesn’t have quite the same bite now that the N.B.A. is playing all of its games in a so-called bubble, but it elicited a hearty laugh from P.J. Tucker of the Houston Rockets regardless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Buoyancy’ Review: Enduring Horrors on the Sea, and Struggling to Survive
description: In this sobering, moving drama, a Cambodian teenager runs away from home and is sold into slavery on a Thai fishing boat.
content: The hollow-eyed man on the fishing boat calls the water “the sea of the dead.” It’s an apt name for this stretch of blue more properly known as the Gulf of Thailand. The water is usually calm in “Buoyancy,” save for the thrash of fish and the churn of the engine. There’s far more turbulence onboard, where the hollow-eyed man and a handful of others rise before the sun and work into the night, though work is too dignified a word to describe this hell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: What if We Have to Wait Years for a Coronavirus Vaccine?
description: A silver-bullet vaccine is far from guaranteed. But it’s also not the only way out of the pandemic.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nafeeza Yahya-Sakur and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Killings Reignite Racial Tensions in Guyana
description: The South American country, already deeply split by a presidential election and an oil windfall, is tested again as three teenagers are slain.
content: COTTON TREE, Guyana — The gruesome murders of two teenagers and the apparent reprisal killing of a third have plunged Guyana into its worst racial unrest in years, coming just weeks after the nation emerged from a disputed election that had deeply divided its two dominant groups over the country’s newfound oil wealth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: A Year of Challenge and Change: Writing Prompts to Help You Reflect on 2020
description: An ongoing list of questions to help teenagers document their lives during a year that will define their generation.
content: As part of the suite of resources we’re creating to help students document their lives during this extraordinary year, we’ve rounded up a list we hope can provide instant inspiration. Here are all the relevant Student Opinion questions we posed on our site this spring, as well as an ongoing list of everything we’re asking this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Now We Know What the President Knew
description: The revelations in Bob Woodward’s book about President Trump also showed us something about the state of the Washington establishment.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: 3 Air National Guard Members Killed in Plane Crash in Tennessee
description: The crash, which occurred near an airport 70 miles southeast of Nashville, is being investigated by the F.A.A. and the National Transportation Safety Board.
content: Three members of the Tennessee Air National Guard are dead after the small plane they were in crashed not far from an airport, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: September 10, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, September 10, 2020
content: An article on Wednesday about helicopter rescue missions during the California wildfires misattributed two quotations. It was Chief Warrant Officer Kipp Goding, not Chief Warrant Officer Joseph Rosamond, who said, “Every piece of vegetation as far as you could see around that lake was on fire.” It was also Mr. Goding who said: “I’ve been flying for 25 years. We get occasionally shot at overseas during missions. It’s definitely by far the toughest flying that I’ve ever done.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: For Survivors at Charlie Hebdo Trial, Wounds Are Still Raw
description: Victims of the 2015 attack on the satirical weekly took the stand this week with vivid accounts of how their colleagues were killed — and how their own lives were suddenly overturned.
content: PARIS — One by one, the witnesses told a hushed court how their lives were brutally upended on a cold January morning in 2015, when two brothers wielding assault rifles burst onto a quiet Parisian street looking for the newsroom of Charlie Hebdo, the satirical weekly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Kate Conger
title: Cleaners Demand Harassment Safeguards From the Booking Service Handy
description: Workers for a home services company say they face sexual harassment and unfair fees. A civil rights group is asking California regulators to step in.
content: BERKELEY, Calif. — It was supposed to be just another routine job for Patti Cris, who in early 2018 was a contract worker for the home services booking site Handy. She got the key for the San Jose apartment she was scheduled to clean while its occupant was gone, and remembers knocking twice and announcing herself, just to make sure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: The Causes of Estrangement, and How Families Heal
description: For those who reconcile with estranged relatives, the key is “letting go of the attempt to have the other person see the past as they saw it,” the author of a new book says.
content: A 21-year-old college student who hasn’t spoken to her mother since high school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: After 43 Years, the Wine Sentinel of the River Café Stands Down
description: Joseph DeLissio, “a blue-collar kid in a white-collar job,” saw the rise of American wine culture and put together an ever-changing, world-class list.
content: Joseph DeLissio never felt called to become a master sommelier. He didn’t post Instagram photos of himself posing with cult wines. He didn’t try to make his own wine, start an import company or initiate a podcast, all standard activities for 21st-century sommeliers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Our Time Machine’ Review: A Picture of the Past
description: In this documentary, the Chinese artist Maleonn enlists his aging parents, both artists themselves, in an ambitious memory play.
content: The Chinese artist who goes by the name Maleonn (his work encompasses puppetry, theater, photography, machine engineering and more) is himself the product of a rich artistic heritage. His mother, Zheng Wei Tong, was an actor, and his father, Ma Ke, directed both the Beijing Opera and the Shanghai Opera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Sokolove
title: How Trump Could Win Pennsylvania Again
description: Can Democrats forestall another landslide in the state’s rural counties?
content: Rick Ainey lives on the northern tier of Pennsylvania, near the New York border in a region known as the Endless Mountains. The area is scenic, deeply rural and so reliably Republican that the last time it has given a majority of its votes to a Democratic presidential candidate was in 1964, when Lyndon Johnson crushed Barry Goldwater just about everywhere. The time before that was 1852, when the two major parties were the Democrats and the Whigs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth
title: Russian Intelligence Hackers Are Back, Microsoft Warns, Aiming at Officials of Both Parties
description: China is also growing more adept at targeting campaign workers. But contrary to Trump administration warnings, Beijing is mostly aiming at Biden campaign officials.
content: The Russian military intelligence unit that attacked the Democratic National Committee four years ago is back with a series of new, more stealthy hacks aimed at campaign staff members, consultants and think tanks associated with both Democrats and Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Sept. 16, 2020
description: How is Covid-19 affecting where you live? What do you notice and wonder about these two maps?
content: The New York Times reports that in the United States there have been more than 6.3 million Covid-19 cases and more than 190,000 deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Is Staying Home Harming Your Child’s Immune System?
description: Why exposure to other germy kids might matter.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has come with a few silver linings. The clear winner for me has been the delightful dearth of snot: My kids haven’t had a cold since March, and neither have I, and I haven’t missed those crusty red noses one little bit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roy Furchgott
title: Chevy’s Little Engine That Could
description: For six decades, a small-block Chevy has powered the dreams of hot-rodders and Corvettes, and plenty of other cars, even a Ford Mustang.
content: In the great rivalry between Chevrolet and Ford, Jason Carlisle, a former mechanic and current hobbyist racer, took sides decades ago. “Cut me: I bleed Ford blue,” he said. But when it came time to replace the engine in his Mustang racecar, he did the unthinkable. He installed a small-block Chevy engine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Announces Dozens of Fraud Charges in Small-Business Aid Program
description: Fifty-seven people were charged with trying to steal more than $175 million from the Paycheck Protection Program, law enforcement officials said.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department said on Thursday that it had charged 57 people with trying to steal more than $175 million from the Paycheck Protection Program to help small businesses during the coronavirus pandemic as questions swirled about how its funds were disbursed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Texas Man Sentenced to Five Years for Planting Bombs in Beaumont
description: Jonathan Matthew Torres “preyed upon Beaumont,” terrifying residents days after a bomb spree in Austin, federal officials said.
content: A Beaumont, Texas, man was sentenced on Wednesday to five years in prison for planting a pair of bombs, terrifying the city in the weeks after a deadly bombing spree rocked Austin in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Unpregnant’ Review: Friendship Is a Long and Winding Road
description: Former besties reunite for a road trip in this teen buddy comedy, which is the second movie this year to feature young women crossing state lines to obtain an abortion.
content: “Unpregnant” is the second film this year, after “Never Rarely Sometimes Always,” to feature a pair of teenage women crossing state lines to obtain an abortion. In both movies, as in real life, the characters’ home states mandate parental consent for minors. But in contrast to that earlier, quietly distressing story, “Unpregnant” takes this real-world issue as the premise for an energetic buddy comedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Dana Rubinstein
title: 150 Big Businesses Warn Mayor of ‘Widespread Anxiety’ Over N.Y.C.’s Future
description: Leaders of companies like Goldman Sachs and JetBlue implored Mayor Bill de Blasio to take more decisive action to halt the city’s decline.
content: More than 150 business leaders in New York City joined together on Thursday to warn Mayor Bill de Blasio that he needed to take more decisive action to address crime and other quality-of-life issues that they said were jeopardizing the city’s economic recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Introducing ‘Sway’ With Kara Swisher
description: A new podcast about power: who has it, who’s been denied it and who dares to defy it.
content: Times Opinion is teaming up with Kara Swisher on a new podcast about power and influence. She’s taking on C.E.O.s, senators, actors and activists — plus upstarts and gatekeepers you might not yet know but need to hear from. How did these people get power? How do they actually use it? And how does their power shape your life?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Coastal Elites’ Review: Confined Confessions
description: This collection of monologues written by Paul Rudnick initially for the stage, has been adapted for the screen.
content: Legend has it that shortly after Shakespeare premiered “Macbeth,” London’s theaters were shuttered by plague. Four centuries later, the playwright and screenwriter Paul Rudnick’s “Coastal Elites,” arriving on HBO Sept. 12, has embraced the soliloquy as the defining art form of the era of social distance, where we poor players strut and fret our hours on the webcam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: For New York City Ballet, Another Digital Season
description: Live performances in the theater are still on hold, but the company will present an online season, culminating in five new dances.
content: New York City Ballet will not be returning to the David H. Koch Theater this fall, but the company’s coming digital season will culminate with performances of new dances by Pam Tanowitz, Jamar Roberts, Justin Peck, Sidra Bell and Andrea Miller. The commissioned ballets will be recorded outdoors in New York City and shared with audiences, one each night, from Oct. 27 to Oct. 31.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leena Trivedi-Grenier
title: A Chef’s Childhood in Iran Shaped His Cooking in the Pandemic
description: In times of crisis, the California chef Hanif Sadr learned to forage and preserve food, and use it to heal.
content: A FOREST IN THE BAY AREA, CALIF. — Moments after walking into a verdant forest in San Francisco’s East Bay, the chef Hanif Sadr nibbled on the vegetation he found there — canary yellow mustard flowers, then spicy wild radish flowers, streaked with white and purple. He tasted potently cool chocolate mint, and sniffed leaves from an intensely aromatic California bay laurel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Takenaga
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A recovery bill sinks, and teachers pay a heavy toll.
content: Don’t expect any new virus stimulus before Election Day. That seems to be the takeaway after Senate Republicans today failed to advance their scaled-back plan, in the face of opposition from Democrats, who called it inadequate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Netanyahu Apology to Bedouins Is Taken as an Affront
description: Critics and outraged officials accused the Israeli prime minister, on trial for corruption, of exploiting a tragic episode to discredit his own law enforcement agencies.
content: JERUSALEM — It took nearly four years for the Israeli government to apologize to a Bedouin family from the Negev desert after a relative whose car had fatally run over a police officer, and who was killed by police fire, was hastily and wrongly labeled a terrorist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy, Mike Baker and Tim Arango
title: States Are in Desperate Search for Help Battling Record Wildfires
description: With millions of acres ablaze across the West Coast, states are having a tough time finding available fire crews. California resorted to calling in a team of firefighters from Israel.
content: MOLALLA, Ore. — As wildfires began consuming communities across Oregon this week, leaders at the state emergency management office fired off an email to counterparts around the country, pleading for 10 firefighting strike teams that could bring 50 extra engines to the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Kelly
title: Mothers for QAnon
description: In the testosterone-filled world of Trump-adjacent online conspiracy, the newest theory stands out. Why are so many women falling for Q?
content: On Aug. 22, I attended a “Freedom for the Children” rally in London, one of hundreds around the world organized by believers in the complicated conspiracy theory known as QAnon. Looking around, it was impossible not to notice a fact that at first glance surprised me: The rally was composed mostly of women, many with young children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel, Hailey Fuchs and Luke Broadwater
title: Postal Service to Tap Republican Lobbyist to Quell Mounting Scrutiny
description: Facing multiple investigations and calls for his ouster, the postmaster general turned to a G.O.P. lobbyist viewed as adept at reaching out to Democrats.
content: WASHINGTON — Postmaster General Louis DeJoy, moving to defend himself and top postal officials against suggestions that they are trying to help President Trump win re-election by sabotaging mail-in voting, told colleagues on Wednesday that he planned to hire a veteran Republican lobbyist to work with Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Documenting Teenage Lives in 2020: A Guide for Participating in Our Contest
description: Four practical steps for cataloging what you already have, deciding what you most want to express, and playing with medium and genre.
content: How has 2020 challenged or changed you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and Christopher Flavelle
title: A Climate Reckoning in Fire-Stricken California
description: If climate change was a somewhat abstract notion a decade ago, today it is all too real for Californians fleeing wildfires and smothered in a blanket of smoke, the worst year of fires on record.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Multiple mega fires burning more than three million acres. Millions of residents smothered in toxic air. Rolling blackouts and triple-digit heat waves. Climate change, in the words of one scientist, is smacking California in the face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Annie Karni
title: As Clock Ticks, Trump Engulfs Himself in Chaotic News Cycles
description: With early voting about to begin in some states, the days President Trump can afford to be consumed by crises of his own making are dwindling. But he has spent the last week in reaction mode.
content: President Trump is running out the clock on his own re-election campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Every Infinitive in Esperanto
description: David J. Kahn gives us an earworm.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — It is apparently Earworm Week at the New York Times Crossword, because I had this song playing in my head all day once I solved the Wednesday puzzle, and now, with the publication of the Thursday crossword, I hear eight very familiar notes repeating themselves, over and over and over again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Space Dogs’ Review: No Dogs Go to Heaven
description: This documentary uses the lives and legends of Moscow’s street dogs to present a brutal vision of humanity and nature.
content: The otherworldly documentary “Space Dogs” begins fittingly with a story of oblivion. A narrator recounts the pioneering flight of Laika, the Muscovite street dog who orbited the Earth when the Soviets launched her into space in 1957. The camera seems to recreate her journey, floating around glowing blue. But this peacefulness derails as the narrator details Laika’s cruel demise and the image begins to distort, as if the camera were making a forced re-entry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: A Black Venture Capitalist Sees Challenges as an Investing Edge
description: “Black Founders Matter” started out as a T-shirt design. Now, a once-jilted start-up founder is trying to turn it into a moneymaking strategy.
content: Marceau Michel’s idea for a new on-demand staffing company, Werkhorse, was good enough to win a start-up pitch competition and a coveted spot in a tech incubator in Portland, Ore., two years ago. But no matter what he did, Mr. Michel could not seem to land the funding he needed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What to Know About the Wildfires
description: Thursday: Taking a step back to answer questions.

title: Jets and Giants Coaches Aim for Wins Using Different Approaches
description: Joe Judge, the Giants’ first-year coach, hopes to energize a team entering a new era, while the Jets’ Adam Gase wants to build consistency for Sam Darnold.
content: The Giants and the Jets have struggled with the injuries, internal dissent and, to put it plainly, winning in recent seasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trump’s Coronavirus Response Was Beyond Incompetent
description: He wasn’t oblivious to the danger. He just didn’t care.
content: Most cases in which cars kill pedestrians surely reflect negligence: drivers who were too busy talking on their cellphones or thinking about their golf games to notice the senior citizen crossing the street in front of them. A handful are acts of murder, like when a man killed a woman by plowing his car into counterprotesters at a neo-Nazi rally in Charlottesville, Va.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: In Berlin Theaters, the Curtain Rises on a ‘Corona Season’
description: Some of the city’s major playhouses are presenting pandemic-delayed premieres in sparsely populated auditoriums, with much of the seating removed.
content: BERLIN — People in Berlin know the drill by now: Wear masks, wash hands, give details for contact tracing and keep a distance from other audience members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Return of the King: Ninja, a Video Game Star, Goes Back to Twitch
description: After months of speculation, one of the world’s most famous video gamers announced his next move.
content: BERKELEY, Calif. — In 2010, LeBron James made “The Decision,” leaving his hometown Cleveland Cavaliers for the Miami Heat and upending the N.B.A.

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: N.F.L. Season Starts With Eyes on Anthem and Pandemic
description: The league stuck to its plans to open its season Thursday with the Kansas City Chiefs hosting the Houston Texans, even as pandemic spikes, player opt-outs and racial unrest forced alterations.
content: The N.F.L. opened its season Thursday night with a game between the Super Bowl champion Kansas City Chiefs and the Houston Texans, a milestone reminder of normalcy during a completely abnormal time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Haskins and Naomi Shihab Nye
title: Poem: The Hedgehog
description: A poem that widens to contain our curiosity, our fear, whatever we’re each keeping contained.
content: Though many like to say that poems begin with “ordinary” things, creatures and experiences, there could never be anything ordinary about a hedgehog. The way it looks, the way it looks back at you, surely the way it feels — astonishing. Lola Haskins’s endearing poem from “Asylum: Improvisations on John Clare” is possibly as straightforward as a poem could be: We’re on a walk with her, then stumble upon an unexpected rustle. What makes this poem sing is the quick instant that the hedgehog image widens to contain us all — our curiosity, our fear, whatever we’re each keeping contained. In that “rush” of empathy is our unexpected lift. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Hardach
title: In Quarantine, Kids Pick Up Parents’ Mother Tongues
description: For some families, the pandemic has meant a return to their native languages.
content: A few days into the lockdown here in London, I noticed a surprising side-effect of the pandemic: My 3-year-old son was speaking more German.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: M.L.B. Set to Hold Postseason at Neutral Sites
description: The league plans to hold games at four stadiums in Southern California and Texas, with the World Series held at the Texas Rangers’ new ballpark.
content: Major League Baseball will play most of its postseason at neutral sites for the first time, with the World Series to be held this October at the Texas Rangers’ new ballpark in Arlington, Texas. While the league is still working out details of the plan with the players’ union, the concept and location of postseason bubbles have been decided.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisann McLane
title: A Freshly Killed Chicken Is Mightier Than the Coronavirus
description: How Hong Kong’s food culture has adapted to epidemic after epidemic, fending off disease while saving its favorite dishes, and its soul.
content: HONG KONG — The other day, craving a bowl of fish ball noodle soup, I went to eat lunch at On Lee, a famous 54-year-old hole-in-the-wall on Hong Kong Island. I hadn’t been there since the start of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna

description: Rebuilding the restaurant business requires a new model for its labor.
content: When the pandemic hit America’s restaurants, it was as if an anvil dropped — on a bubble.

description: Set in the 1990s, this thriller features Wil Wheaton — on a videotape — as a bearded, sweater-vest wearing “friend” to a lonely man.
content: This thriller, the debut feature from Jon Stevenson — who not only wrote, produced and directed it, but was also the editor — does a lot of things well. Or almost well. But finally, not well enough.

title: Support the Brave Protesters of Belarus
description: America and Europe must make clear that they stand behind the Belarusian people’s demand for fair elections.
content: The monthlong crackdown on peaceful protests over a blatantly fixed election in Belarus is an affront to everyone who cherishes democracy and elemental fairness. The question is how to respond.

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: The Woodward Revelations
description: In March, Trump admitted he was downplaying the coronavirus: This is your morning tip sheet.

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Andy Newman
title: A poll finds most Americans are worried the Trump administration will rush a virus vaccine.
description: A clear majority of American adults worry that political pressure from the Trump administration will lead the Food and Drug Administration to rush through a coronavirus vaccine without making sure it is safe and effective, according to a poll released Thursday by the Kaiser Family Foundation.
content: A clear majority of American adults worry that political pressure from the Trump administration will lead the Food and Drug Administration to rush through a coronavirus vaccine without making sure it is safe and effective, according to a poll released Thursday by the Kaiser Family Foundation.

content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

author: By Peter Baker
title: For a President Who ‘Needs to Touch the Flame,’ Bob Woodward Was Irresistible
description: President Trump gave 18 interviews to the famed Watergate journalist, gambling that he could control the narrative. Instead, he undermined himself shortly before an election.
content: WASHINGTON — Presidents over the decades thought they could manage Bob Woodward and many, as Karl Rove put it this week, came to regret it. Then came Donald J. Trump, who being Donald J. Trump thought so much of his powers of persuasion that he opened up to Mr. Woodward not once or twice but an astonishing 18 times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Black Boys’ Review: Young Lives in the Balance
description: This documentary addresses the dehumanization of Black boys by attempting the reverse: reconstructing them to show they are worth the care they are denied.
content: When does the eye of the documentarian obscure the sight? The Peacock film “Black Boys” examines the beauty of Black boys but suffers from a failure to police its own gaze.

author: By Gia Kourlas and Angelo Vasta
title: Trading the Ice for New York City Pavement
description: Under the summer sun, Ice Theater of New York finds its way back to gliding. “I go wherever my wheels take me,” one skater says.
content: A sheet of ice, a metal blade and speed. With each stroke of a blade, the surface melts away, leaving a canvas of etchings. At the same time, a skater experiences that treasured sensation: the ability to glide.

author: By Thomas Kaplan
title: Democrats are sending a truck to Trump’s Michigan rally to play audio of his coronavirus comments.
description: Ahead of President Trump’s rally in Michigan on Thursday night, Democrats are planning to use his own words to skewer him.

description: The museum adds a midcareer component to a program known for anointing new talent.
content: The artist-in-residence program at the Studio Museum in Harlem is an institution — an early-career incubator whose alumni list, in annual cohorts of three, reads like a canon of a half-century of Black American art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and John Schwartz
title: These Changes Are Needed Amid Worsening Wildfires, Experts Say
description: The blazes scorching the West highlight the urgency of rethinking fire management policies, as climate change threatens to make things worse.
content: Wildfires are ravaging the West — in California alone, five of the largest blazes on record have all struck in just the past four years — offering a deadly reminder that the nation is far behind in adopting policies widely known to protect lives and property, even though worsening fires have become a predictable consequence of climate change.
